history.content: Piazza is a Q&A platform designed to get you great answers from classmates and instructors fast. We've put together this list of tips you might find handy as you get started: 1. Ask questions! The best way to get answers is to ask questions! Ask questions on Piazza rather than emailing your teaching staff so everyone can benefit from the response (and so you can get answers from classmates who are up as late as you are). 2. Edit questions and answers wiki-style. Think of Piazza as a Q&A wiki for your class. Every question has just a single students' answer that students can edit collectively (and a single instructors’ answer for instructors). 3. Add a followup to comment or ask further questions. To comment on or ask further questions about a post, start a followup discussion. Mark it resolved when the issue has been addressed, and add any relevant information back into the Q&A above. 4. Go anonymous. Shy? No problem. You can always opt to post or edit anonymously. 5. Tag your posts. It's far more convenient to find all posts about your Homework 3 or Midterm 1 when the posts are tagged. Type a “#” before a key word to tag. Click a blue tag in a post or the question feed to filter for all posts that share that tag. 6. Format code and equations. Adding a code snippet? Click the pre or tt button in the question editor to add pre-formatted or inline teletype text. Mathematical equation? Click the Fx button to access the LaTeX editor to build a nicely formatted equation. 7. View and download class details and resources. Click the Course Page button in your top bar to access the class syllabus, staff contact information, office hours details, and course resources—all in one place! Contact the Piazza Team anytime with questions or comments at team@piazza.com. We love feedback!
history.subject: Welcome to Piazza!

This is a problem that will apply to all foreign students. In homework 1, we outline two options for you:
1) Sign up as a CrowdFlower worker instead of a Mechanical Turk worker. CF has a larger international workforce. 
2) Borrow a MTurk worker account from one of your friends.

http://crowdsourcing-class.org/assignment1.html

My account was approved for Mechanical Turk, but then it told me to sign up for Amazon Payments. When I tried to sign up for Amazon Payments, it asked me for an SSN. As an international student, I don't have an SSN yet. What should I do?

history.content:
Please register to be a worker on Amazon Mechanical Turk TODAY at https://www.mturk.com/mturk/welcome 
You will need an account to for the first homework assignment.  We will be doing a walk through on Friday, and it would be great if you have your account activated by then.  Typically it takes Amazon several days to activate workers accounts, so please create yours ASAP.
Note that all foreign students, and some domestic students had problems creating Mechanical Turk accounts last year.  If you have a problem, please try to sign up to be a Crowd Flower worker (also called a "contributor"). You can sign up here: https://elite.crowdflower.com/?view=register
--CCB

history.content:
There's a really interesting talk tomorrow - I'd encourage you to attend if you're able! 

Thursday, January 14 / 4:30 pm

Silverstein Forum, Stiteler Hall

University of Pennsylvania Campus

 

Abstract: 

IMAGINE IF GOVERNMENT COULD QUICKLY GET ADVICE from infectious disease experts in the event of a pandemic, or find and reach out to cyber-security professionals following an infrastructure attack, or pose questions about our public challenges to data scientists. From combatting terrorism to safeguarding the future of the planet, society will confront unprecedented challenges over the next decades. To succeed, Noveck argues, we have to run our institutions differently. Getting ideas from outside - often called crowdsourcing or open innovation - should be just as vital for the improvement of public institutions as it has been for success in commerce and science. Data science tools hold the potential to transform how we govern by making it possible to solve hard problems through the diverse and distributed expertise of the many citizens who would be willing to contribute their talents, skills, expertise and enthusiasm to the public good.

 

Excerpt: "Changing how we make decisions will depend squarely on having the personnel who embrace openness and collaboration. The recognition of citizen expertise does not mean jettisoning the professionals and substituting some kind of web-based plebiscite-far from it. Making good use of citizen expertise will require even better-trained managers and leaders. This new breed of professional-if we can call it that with a wink and a nod-will need to know how to work and talk and decide with citizens rather than for them. Just as the next generation will need to know how to govern with big and open data, predictive analytics, and real-time indicators, they will also need to develop the skillset for managing the conversation to get at the intelligence necessary to govern in a complex society." - From Smart Citizens, Smarter State
history.subject: Cool talk tomorrow - Crowdsourcing Smartly: Is Democracy Prepared to Flip the Big Data Switch?

children.subject: Have you heard anything since? Which address did you use (home or school)? The easiest way to move forward on this, since Amazon tends to have limited customer service for Mechanical Turk, is to find a friend who was able to complete the assignment and use their account.

They emailed me back:

When I created my account, I used my home address, which is here in Philadelphia.

This also happened to me. Everything was fine until they asked for my payment information. Now, I'm locked out of my account.

Is this the email you got?
I have the same issue as well even though I provided all the information asked for.
Many students has this problem last year. I suggest trying the alternatives that we laid out in HW1.
How did you get them to ask for your government ID? They just flat out told me no.

This is the email I originally got: 

"We appreciate your use of Amazon Payments.  Unfortunately, we have been unable to confirm your account information.  This may be because you failed to respond to our past requests for more information or we could not confirm identity information provided by you.
In either case, we are now required to restrict your Amazon Payments account features.
We apologize for any resulting inconvenience and appreciate your understanding of our need to take this action."

Then I went back on mturk and tried re-signing up. Then they sent me this:

"We are writing with regards to your Amazon Payments account. It appears that your account is on hold as we have not been able to verify your account information.
In order to verify your account information, please provide the following:
1. A copy of unexpired, U.S. government-issued photographic identification (driver license, ID, Passport, Green Card, etc). Please note that we do not accept temporary IDs (such as an interim Driver’s License or a Learner’s Permit).
Please fax this documentation to our toll free fax number 1-800-887-0540. To ensure that your fax is processed in a timely manner, please be sure to include the email address associated with your AmazonPayments account."

So sign up again, try that.
Sorry for all the questions. When you say sign up again, do you mean for MTurk or for Amazon Payments?
MTurk will ask you to validate Amazon Payments through their  site; it should transfer you over. You can email me if you  can't get it to work: brodylan@sas

Y'all, If they fail to validate twice, they may ask for a government ID. This  happened to me, and if you fax them  the information at the number they send you, tthey got back to me within a few hours. There are free fax services online, just fyi.

One more question: Did any of your HITs appear in the Track section?  Or did none of them appear there?
I only had 1 of the HITs appear in the Track section. Every other task was not tracked.

Here is an update from my developer: "I've checked the user - all the HITs do appear on the Track page. The fact that they were missing could be because the background process that calculates whether a user is qualified for a hitgroup is overrun with requests to recalculated qualified status for all hitgroups for new users. Computing such statuses for a single user takes about 15 minutes, and since there were a lot of new users, it takes a while to work through them. At the moment I'm working on making it faster (there are a lot of entries in the database as we include  also historical hit groups). There was also a problem displaying not qualified HITs on Track page - this should be fine now."  

Can you check the track page again (reload the page on your browser) and tell me if you see the info now?

history.content: Michael Bernstein hosted a panel discussion last night that is very related to today's lecture.  Michael is a professor at Stanford University who does research on crowdsourcing.  He and his team are trying to design a new platform for micro-tasking-style crowd work that is more fair to workers.  The panel consisted of several requesters (including me) and several workers. Here's a YouTube video of the hour-long panel discussion.
history.subject: Video of Crowd Research Workers-Requesters Panel

children.subject:
That's a good question.  Part of the difficulty in establishing a fair wage on Mechanical Turk is the fact that it has an international workforce.  A HIT that pays $2/hour is not a fair wage in the USA, but may go further in other countries like India. 

This also raises a question about whether the US minimum wage is really a fair wage.  The US federal minimum wage is $7.25/hour.  Fast food workers in many cities have staged walkouts to try to secure a $15/hour minimum wage.  The federal minimum wage is actually lower for wait staff and other tipped workers.  Their minimum wage is $2.13 per hour, if you can believe it. 

Professor Amy Glassier of MIT has a Living Wage Calculator that estimates a livable wage in every county in the USA, making assumptions about the local costs of food, housing and other basic needs.
Another group who earn less than the minimum wages are prisoners.  Inmates earn from $0.23/hour up to a maximum of $1.15/hour working for UNICOR.

I find it interesting to bring up the international workforce idea into the MTurk site. When it's put in that perspective (along with wait staff and tipped workers), the wages on MTurk does not seem as bad as it looks. For US workers, it seems that the only way to reach that minimum wage of $7.25/hour would be with Master's Qualification.
What would be a reasonable "minimum" wage for Turkers? Should it be the U.S. minimum wage?

  2. cd ~/
  3. virtualenv nets213
  4. source nets213/bin/activate
  5. pip install ipython[notebook]
  6. ipython notebook This creates a virtual environment that has IPython Notebook.

  2. source nets213/bin/activate

history.content:
Here's a cool example of the interaction between crowdsourcing and machine learning, applied to poetry:

http://motherboard.vice.com/read/how-machines-write-poetry

"For an objective assessment of her program’s work, Harmon recruited subjects from Amazon Mechanical Turk. In a pilot study, people read FIGURE8’s more complex sentences. But the task seemed to wear them out. “It became more of an English assignment,” she says. So for the study she presented at this year’s International Conference on Computational Creativity, Harmon restricted her program to simple sentences that fit certain patterns. It wasn’t FIGURE8’s most thrilling writing, but these shorter phrases would be easier for subjects to compare.

Each person read sets of five FIGURE8 sentences at a time. People ranked the similes for their clarity, as well as how enjoyable they were to read. Harmon then compared those ratings to scores the computer program had given itself for clarity and overall quality. Harmon found that her subjects’ ratings were pretty close to how FIGURE8 rated itself. For example, humans and computer agreed that The queen stands like a strong castle was a good, clear simile. But they also agreed that It was her pearl, crumpling like a drowned corpse didn’t make much sense."
history.subject: Crowdsourcing used to evaluate success of poetry-generating robot

history.content:
There are. Later in the semester, you'll be selecting a paper on Mechanical Turk (or crowdsourcing in general, though some use MTurk and crowdsourcing interchangeably) and recreating the results of it. Some of the more positive examples I can think of are very enthusiastic about its applications for real-time interfaces. If you're interested, you might want to check out some of the below (but hold off on actually implementing them until the specifics of the assignment are released). I was able to find both online (legally) for free. 

Crowds in Two Seconds: Enabling Realtime Crowd­Powered Interfaces by Michael Bernstein, Joel Brandt, Rob Miller, and David Karger

Exploring Iterative and Parallel Human Computation Processes by Greg Little, Lydia B. Chilton, Max Goldman, and Robert C. Miller

children.subject:
Absolutely! I don't think there is a single topic in academia on which there are not conflicting opinions. :-) 

I, personally, have a positive view of crowdsourcing, as does Chris (I assume, I'll let him speak for himself) or we wouldn't be teaching the course. As with any kind of (especially economic/technical) progress, there is just a lot of nuance that goes into maximizing the good and minimizing the bad. That is why people are probably more inclined to point out flaws than successes. 

A lot of the most positive reports of crowdsourcing, like Kate mentioned, are from the perspective of "look at all the great technologies that crowdsourcing enables." You can check out some crowdsourcing conferences web pages to see what some of the most forward-looking applications are. HCOMP and UIST are good conferences to check out.

http://www.aaai.org/Library/HCOMP/hcomp15contents.php

http://uist.acm.org/uist2015/papers

Mary L. Gray (now at Microsoft, I think) also does some very interesting work on crowdsourcing and labor markets, and has an optimistic but still realistic outlook. I saw her give a talk about communities and collaborations among Turkers, and it was very inspiring. She has a lot of interesting things to say: http://www.inthecrowd.org/

history.content:
Hi Everyone!

Sorry class got so rushed-- I was hoping to walk through more of the bootcamp. Hopefully you were able to get a good start. We have back to back office hours now and office hours from noon until 8 tomorrow, so come get help early! 

Attached is the iPython notebook from class today, which takes care of question 1 for you. The relevant code is also below. You should be able to recycle it in some shape or form for most of the other questions in the assignment. 

#This line reads in full text of the file, the splits it up using the newline character ('\n')
#The return value (stored in wine) is a list of strings, each one corresponding to a line in the file
#Fun fact: This is the same as calling open('data/wine.txt').read().split('\n')
wine = open('data/wine.txt').readlines()

ratings = {} #dictionary keep track of how many times each star value is seen
for line in wine:
    review_and_rating = line.strip().split('\t') #split each line into two strings, using the tab character
    stars = review_and_rating[1]
    if stars not in ratings: #check if the key is in the dictionary. If not, add it and give it a count of 0
        print("adding", stars, "to ratings")
        ratings[stars] = 0
    ratings[stars] += 1 #increment the count by 1
    
for key in ratings:
    print(key, "appeared", ratings[key], "times")

Please ask questions!

IPythonBootcamp.ipynb

history.content:
Hi everyone,

 

For your python bootcamp, and for many other assignments this semester, you will be using 'turnin', which is a program on eniac. This requires using the 'ssh' and 'scp' commands from your terminal. Instructions on how to do this are below, but please come to office hours if this whole process looks foreign to you. It will take about 30 seconds to show you in person, versus much longer than 30 seconds of playing guess-and-check on your own. :) 

You will be turning in your entire iPython notebook. Once you have your notebook copied over to the eniac machines and sshed yourself over to the eniac machines (instructions below), you will run.

 

turnin -c nets213 -p python-bootcamp -v IPythonBootcamp.ipynb

 

Here is the process, from the beginning. The lines beginning with '$' or '~>' are things you will need to type. Lines beginning with '#' are comments, explaining the commands below. Lines that have no special characters at the show the output you should expect to see.

#Copy your iPython file (which right now is on your computer) to your account on the eniac. You can do this using the 'scp' or 'secure copy' command, like below.
$ scp IPythonBootcamp.ipynb epavlick@eniac.seas.upenn.edu:               
epavlick@eniac.seas.upenn.edu's password: 
IPythonBootcamp.ipynb           

#Log on to the  eniac machines (using your usual penn username/password). You should see your command prompt change to say something like @plus or @minus, like below.
$ ssh epavlick@eniac.seas.upenn.edu
epavlick@eniac.seas.upenn.edu's password: 
Last login: Wed Jan 27 14:46:24 2016 from 10.251.134.177
epavlick@plus:~> 

#Make sure your file was copied over successfully. You can check by listing the contents of the current directory using the 'ls' command. Hopefully you will see many things listed, and your IPython file should be one of them.
epavlick@plus:~> ls 
Desktop  Documents  Downloads  IPythonBootcamp.ipynb

#You can keep things organized by making a new folder for this assignment using the "mkdir" command, and moving your file into it using the "mv" command. See below.
epavlick@plus:~> mkdir python-bootcamp-submission
epavlick@plus:~> mv IPythonBootcamp.ipynb python-bootcamp-submission/

#To see the list of open projects for our class, type the following. Currently, only the bootcamp and the test project are open.
epavlick@plus:~> turnin -l -c nets213

the-end          off
test-turnin      on (current)

# To submit your bootcamp to turnin, use the following command. The

drwxr-xr-x epavlick/epavlick 0 2016-01-27 15:53 python-bootcamp-submission/
-rw-r----- epavlick/epavlick 16606 2016-01-27 15:48 python-bootcamp-submission/IPythonBootcamp.ipynb
Compressing submitted files... please wait
Your files have been submitted to nets213, python-bootcamp for grading.

  

If you want to practice, please try submitting to the test project (called test-turnin), just to make sure everything is working smoothly. You can just submit a blank file, or you are welcome to go on a meaningless rant and submit that. Whatever makes you happy. 

Please let us know if you have any problems or questions.

Ellie

history.content:
Don't worry about tab alignments and formatting differences as long as your data is correct. If you have a tie in the value of a word, you can probably resolve it to match the key by sorting alphabetically in the case of a tie. If you're missing words entirely, or your values are off, there's probably a discrepancy in how you're filtering or cleaning up the words and you'll want to fix that. 

That said, do not just print out your answers as python lists or dictionaries. E.g. 

This (with tabs) is okay:

******	3
*****	53
****	177
***	499
**	162
*	43

So is this (with spaces)

****** 3
***** 53
**** 177
*** 499
** 162
* 43

This is NOT okay:

{******: 3, *****: 53, ****: 177, ***: 499, **: 162, *: 43}

Don't worry about tab alignments and formatting differences as long as your data is correct. If you have a tie in the value of a word, you can probably resolve it to match the key by sorting alphabetically in the case of a tie. If you're missing words entirely, or your values are off, there's probably a discrepancy in how you're filtering or cleaning up the words and you'll want to fix that.

history.content:
Hi Everyone,

Many of you had trouble with turnin for the bootcamp, and sent us email submissions. As a general policy, we cannot accept submissions via email. For this assignment, we will not penalize late submissions, so if you have not yet submitted via turnin, or you are still having trouble using scp/ssh, reach out to us and let's get it figured out. 

For future assignments, we will only consider an assignment to be submitted if it is submitted via turnin before the deadline. Keep in mind our late-day policy: you are allowed 5 total late days during the semester with no penalty. After that, we deduct one point per day late.

Everyone have a wonderful weekend!

Ellie

history.subject: Error testing classifier_template

history.content:
There are a couple of different ways to approach it, and you should try it out multiple ways. It might work better to rule articles in, then rule them out, by keyword all at once (single statement). It might be better to do it sequentially. You can have conditional logic (something like this):

if "word1" in text:
    prediction = 1
else "word2" in text:
    prediction = 1
else if "word3" in text and "word4" not in text:
    prediction = 0

Not sure I follow. You can have conditional logic (something like this)

if "word1" in text:
    prediction = 1
else "word2" in text:
    prediction = 1
else if "word3" in text and "word4" not in text:
    prediction = 0
Should we have a single if-and-or statement with all of the keywords we use? Or should we have a series of if statements when checking keywords?

Did you run the Graphviz installer?

Try

conda install graphviz

or

sudo port install graphviz

http://conda.pydata.org/docs/install/quick.html#os-x-miniconda-install

https://www.macports.org/install.php
but earlier I did "sudo pip install "graphviz" and that worked

Different packages behave differently with different installers. Sometimes it just makes sense to reinstall it from scratch using a separate installer. To make sure the old installation doesn't affect your reinstall, run this command first

sudo pip uninstall graphviz
I did that, and "conda install graphviz" and "pip install graphviz"

You don't want to compound the effect of multiple installers. Run just the following commands and then your code.

$ sudo pip uninstall graphviz
$ conda install graphviz
$ conda install scipy
$ conda install numpy
$ conda install scikit-learn

history.content: Yes, that is more than high enough.

After testing a bunch of words in the rule based classifier, we saw that using only a few words gave us the highest accuracy of .94572. Is this a high enough accuracy?

Adding other words just lowered the accuracy so we aren't sure if we should continue given the fact we arent using a lot of words. We tried but most individual words we added had pretty low accuracies alone. Here is the snippet and the uncommented code is the one that we are using.

Just want to make sure being drawing out the tree and adding to the decision tree classifier, thanks!

		# if "gun" in text : prediction = '1'
		# if "shooting" in text : prediction = '1'
		# if "shot" in text : prediction = '1'
		# if "killed" in text : prediction = '1'
		# if "violence" in text : prediction = '1'
		# if "murder" in text : prediction = '1'
		# if "crime" in text : prediction = '1'
		# if "sentence" in text : prediction = '1'

history.content:
Hey All,

So there have been a lot of questions on Piazza regarding errors and incompatibility issues. I've outlined a few suggestions below to make your life easier with regards getting through them.

1. Using Piazza.

Remotely debugging system issues are pretty challenging. To ensure that we can get an answer to you faster - please specify (a) The System you're using (Mac, Windows, Linux etc.) and how many bits (b) Which installer you used (Pip vs. Conda) (c) If you're running the VM or not. 

2. Search through Piazza

More often than not the answer is already there on Piazza. Try and look through previous questions (especially ones endorsed by an instructor) to see if that solves your problem.

3. Using Stack Overflow

The best way to learn cool things and debug issues is to use the power of Crowdsourcing! Stack Overflow will definitely have the answer to your questions. As you take more advanced classes you'll need StackOverflow to try and debug more complicated issues so it will be super useful to get a head start right now. If you're ever in doubt of what StackOverflow is asking you to do - feel free to post the link and ask on Piazza.

4. Using the VM

Sometimes it makes more sense to just use a different platform which is pre-configured instead of trying to figure out why it doesn't work on your system. So I'd suggest to everyone to use the VM. It's also super useful to get a hang of Linux (it's a rite of passage of sorts for any CS student). 

5. Office Hours

Chances are if the above 3 haven't helped, Office Hours are the place to go. There are plenty spread throughout the week and more often than not you'll have at least one friendly NETS 213 TA hanging around Engineering - So swing by Office hours! 

#pin

history.content:
If any of you are getting the following screen when you download and run the VM, chances are you are trying to run a 64-Bit Ubuntu Disk Image with a 32-Bit Ubuntu configuration on VirtualBox. Make sure you select the 64-bit Ubuntu version. If this option isn't showing up for you, you need to go and change a setting in your BIOS.

1. Reboot your computer

2. Keep F2 pressed 

3. Enter BIOS mode

4. In BIOS mode, navigate to either the Security / Configuration tab

5. You need to find the "Intel Virtualization" option and Enable it.

6. Restart your computer. You should have the 64-bit option enabled now.

If you're uncomfortable doing this by yourself, swing by office hours.

These links may be useful

http://www.thewindowsplanet.com/3192/how-to-enable-virtualization-on-a-lenovo-computer-on-windows.htm

http://www.fixedbyvonnie.com/2014/11/virtualbox-showing-32-bit-guest-versions-64-bit-host-os/#.VrEYOhgrI1I

history.content:
Strictly speaking - yes. But every Machine Learning researcher will tell you that getting a 100% clean dataset is next to impossible. Thus we use multiple thousands of articles to dilute the effect of such noise in the dataset. 

If you're interested in seeing how good a classifier you came up with - train your classifier and then check what it predicts this article to be. If your classifier is robust it will classify this as a non-gun related article.

A bit more:

Chris likely discussed this in class. But keep in mind how the training data was collected. We crawled a blog to collect gun articles (you will repeat this process next week) and we sampled random articles as non-gun articles. Both of these steps are imperfect. This is a fact of life when you are trying to build ML models-- perfectly clean training data is expensive and time-consuming to build, whereas good-enough data is cheap (or free) and fast to get. So we often just go with the latter and pray our models are robust enough to deal with it (they usually are).

Strictly speaking - yes. But every Machine Learning researcher will tell you that getting a 100% clean dataset is next to impossible. Thus we use multiple thousands of articles to dilute the effect of such noise in the dataset. 

If you're interested in seeing how good a classifier you came up with - train your classifier and then check what it predicts this article to be. If your classifier is robust it will classify this as a non-gun related article.

My training classifier marks this article as gun related, but the articles.gz marks the label as non gun related

Our definition of gun related pertains to specific, first-news-reports of instances of gun violence. For the same reason that a discussion of gun violence statistics or gun violence policy wouldn't get flagged by your classifier, this one isn't. This is an article about the trial of George Zimmerman, which would be included as something to flag negative in the directions that the Turkers received.
Though it's definitely fair to say that the case is gun-related, for the classifier our definition is a little more specific.

Is this your statistical classifier? Are you marking articles as positive, then as negative, in your classifier? It could be that something in your ordering is causing this article to be misclassified.

Are you working on the statistical classifier portion? If so, randomly shuffle the data and then use random splits during the cross-validation method. If you want to make sure the random splits are the same every time you run it, you can "seed" the random number generator at the start of the file, which should make it so the results are reproducible. history.content:
You can think of it as simply a series of binary decisions. With the format you have, you are basically building a tree that is always right-branching. Something like

                             word1

                               /    \

                            1    word2

                                     /    \

                                   1    word3

                                            /    \

                                          1     word4

                                                   /     \

                                                 1     etc...

This is a very inefficient, pathological tree structure for some things. :-) But it is fine for what we are doing, and exactly the same structure as what I built, because it is easier for humans to think like this.

When you look at your output when running the DT training algorithm, you will hopefully see a more balanced tree. This is because part of the decision tree's objective is to ask the most efficient questions possible. I.e. it wants to make sure the word at the root is whichever word does the best job of separating gun articles from non-gun articles. Usually it uses a metric called entropy, which you probably read about in the DT chapter.

Does that help at all?

children.subject: Oh, yes, definitely. It doesn't really matter whether it branches right or left. I think the trees are isomorphic, and so equivalent for most practical purposes.

word6    0                  0     word6

children.subject: Neither X nor y is actually "the number of articles". Think about what X and y represent. y is the vector containing the true labels on the articles (one label per article). X is a matrix containing the feature vectors that you extract (one feature vector per article). So X and y need to line up on some dimension-- and line up with the number of articles-- in order to make sense.

Yes. This is usually due to resource starvation like excessive memory use or a program hitting resource limits on shared systems (like eniac). 

In general, the easiest/best solution is to move to a machine with more memory. You should have an account on biglab. Try:

The biglab machines should have more than enough memory for what we will do in this class.

history.content:
So your code is running on my machine but I can suggest a few things that might reduce your memory footprint.

Firstly you're reading your stopwords correctly. Try something like this.

stopwords = [w.rstrip().lower() for w in open('stopwords.txt').readlines()]

Second, make sure all your words are in lower case. That will ensure that "Brown" and "brown" aren't considered different words.

My script runs forever on my virtual machine, so I'm running it off of biglab. I got the statistical analysis to work once (took about 2 minutes), but after un-commenting get_top_features and get_misclassified, my script gets killed before finishing the initial statistical analysis. I've tried several times and I'm unsure what the issue is; I've copied my code below.

#!/bin/python

import os
import sys
import string
import random
import operator
from sklearn.tree import export_graphviz
from sklearn.tree import DecisionTreeClassifier
from sklearn.naive_bayes import MultinomialNB
from sklearn.linear_model import LogisticRegression
from sklearn.preprocessing import LabelEncoder
from sklearn.feature_extraction import DictVectorizer
from sklearn.cross_validation import train_test_split
from sklearn.externals.six import StringIO  

#read in raw data from file and return a list of (label, article) tuples
def get_data(filename): 
	data = [line.strip().split('\t') for line in open(filename).readlines()]
	random.shuffle(data)
	return data

#this function builds the feature matrix for the Decision Tree.
def get_dtree_features(X) :
	features = []
	#TODO : Add the features you would like to use to train the Decision Tree here.
	feature_list = ['gun', 'shooter', 'shot', 'shooting', 'player', 'coach', 'game', 'movie', 'actor', 'film', 'bullet', 'photo', 'model', 'point', 'suspect', 'victim', 'police', 'fired']
	for x in X :
		f = {}
		for w in [word.strip(string.punctuation) for word in x.split()]:
			if w in feature_list : 
				f[w] = 1.0
		features.append(f)
	return features


#this is the main function you care about; pack all the cleverest features you can think of into here.
def get_features(X) :
	stopwords = open('stopwords.txt').read()
	features = []
	for x in X :
		f = {}
		for w in [word.strip(string.punctuation) for word in x.split()]:
			if w not in stopwords:            
				if w not in f : 
					f[w] = 0
				f[w] += 1                
		features.append(f)
	return features

#vectorize feature dictionaries and return feature and label matricies
def get_matricies(data, typ="unigram") : 
	dv = DictVectorizer(sparse=True) 
	le = LabelEncoder()
	y = [d[0] for d in data]
	texts = [d[1] for d in data]
	if typ == "tree":
		X = get_dtree_features(texts)
	else :
		X = get_features(texts)
	#Here we are returning 5 things, the label vector y and feature matrix X, but also the texts from which the features were extracted and the 
	#objects that were used to encode them. These will come in handy for your analysis, but you can ignore them for the initial parts of the assignment
	return le.fit_transform(y), dv.fit_transform(X), texts, dv, le

#train and multinomial naive bayes classifier
def train_classifier(X, y):
	clf = LogisticRegression()
	clf.fit(X,y)
	return clf 

#train a Decision Tree classifier
def train_dtree_classifier(X, y):
	clf = DecisionTreeClassifier(max_depth=10)
	clf.fit(X,y)
	return clf

#test the classifier
def test_classifier(clf, X, y):
	return clf.score(X,y)

#cross validation	
def cross_validate(X, y, dv=None, typ="unigram", numfolds=5,):
	test_accs = []
	split = 1.0 / numfolds
	for i in range(numfolds):
		x_train, x_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=split, random_state=i)
		if typ == "tree" :
			clf = train_dtree_classifier(x_train, y_train)
		else :
			clf = train_classifier(x_train, y_train)
		test_acc = test_classifier(clf, x_test, y_test)
		test_accs.append(test_acc)
		print 'Fold %d : %.05f'%(i,test_acc)
	test_average = float(sum(test_accs))/ numfolds
	if typ == "tree" :
		with open("output.dot", 'w') as f:
			f = export_graphviz(clf, out_file=f, feature_names=dv.get_feature_names(), class_names=['Non Gun Related','Gun Related'])
		create_graph("decision-tree.png")
	print 'Test Average : %.05f'%(test_average)
	print
	return test_average

#run a rule based classifier and calculate the accuracy
def rule_based_classifier(data):
	correct = 0.0; total = 0.0
	for label, text in data : 
		prediction = '0'
		#TODO add more keywords, see how well they do alone and in combination
		if "shooter" in text or "shot" in text or "shooting" in text :
			if "player" in text or "coach" in text or "game" in text: 
				prediction = '0'
			elif "movie" in text or "film" in text or "actor" in text:
				prediction = '0'
			else : prediction = '1'
		if "gun" in text : prediction = '1'
		if prediction == label : correct += 1
		total += 1
	print 'Rule-based classifier accuracy: %.05f'%(correct / total)

#Extra Credit Rule Based Classifier
def extra_credit_classifier(data):
	correct = 0.0; total = 0.0
	for label, text in data : 
		prediction = '0'
		#TODO develop your conditional statements here
		if "shooting" in text : prediction = '1'
		if prediction == label : correct += 1
		total += 1
	print 'Reverse Engineered classifier accuracy: %.05f'%(correct / total)

#train and multinomial naive bayes classifier
def get_top_features(X, y, dv):
	clf = train_classifier(X, y)
	#the DictVectorizer object remembers which column number corresponds to which feature, and return the feature names in the correct order
	feature_names = dv.get_feature_names() 

	#The below code will get the weights from the classifier, and print out the weights of the features you are interested in
	features = [] #this will be a list of (feature_idx, weight) tuples
	for i,w in enumerate(clf.coef_[0]): 
		features.append((i,w))
	#Sort the list by values, with the largest ones first
	features = sorted(features, key=lambda e: e[1], reverse=True)

        #Print out the feature names and thier weights
	for i,w in features:
	  print '%s\t%s'%(feature_names[i], w)

def get_misclassified_examples(y, X, texts) :
	x_train, x_test, y_train, y_test, train_texts, test_texts = train_test_split(X, y, texts)
	clf = train_classifier(x_train, y_train)

	#TODO: You will have to write some code to call your classifier on each of the test examples, and check whether its prediction was right or wrong

def create_graph(file_name) :
	os.system("dot -Tpng output.dot -o " + file_name)
	os.unlink("output.dot")

if __name__ == '__main__' : 

	raw_data = get_data(sys.argv[1])
	
	print '\nRule-based classification'
	rule_based_classifier(raw_data)

################ Decision Tree ################

# print '\nDecision Tree classification'
# y, X, texts, dv, le = get_matricies(raw_data, "tree")
# cross_validate(X,y,dv,"tree")

################ Statistical Classification ################
print '\nStatistical classification'
y, X, texts, dv, le = get_matricies(raw_data)
cross_validate(X,y)

get_top_features(X, y, dv)
get_misclassified_examples(y, X, texts)

history.subject: Invalid config file

history.content:
Hi Everyone!

We have finished grading your company profiles, and I wanted to highlight some common misunderstandings (if that is the right word) that cropped up in many of your assignments. As we go forward in the class, and especially as you all begin to think about your final projects, make sure you are keeping a very open mind of what constitutes "crowdsourcing." Don't get too stuck in the Mechanical Turk/Crowdflower/micro-tasking mindset. 

1. Users vs. Contributors-- Many of you seemed confused about what constitutes a user vs. a contributor. In many crowdsourcing companies, this line is blurry- or nonexistent! Many companies you looked at fit what can be thought of as a "data-mining" model (e.g. Yelp, Foursquare), in which the primary service being provided depends on using data and modeling observed patterns of behavior-- e.g. to target ads or to recommend products. In these cases, the users are the contributors-- everyone who participates provides data, and everyone uses everyone else's data. This is an awesome crowdsourcing model because it is (ideally) self-sustaining and self-incentivizing. The more a person contributes (by providing more data about themselves), the better product they receive (e.g. better recommendations). 

2. Aggregation-- Many of the companies we look at fit into the "match-making" or "marketplace" model (e.g. Uber, Airbnb, Etsy). This is a very common case in which the company is simply working to match supply with demand, where the suppliers (e.g. drivers, in the case of Uber) and the consumers (riders) are distributed all over, and may have trouble finding one another otherwise. Here, rating systems etc. are one piece of the platform that might require aggregating, but arguably the more interesting aggregation problem is how to match a supplier with a consumer. Is this through preference-based recommendation systems (as in the data-mining model discussed above), through location-based matching, through bidding/price? Making these matches is non-trival, but crucial to making the company function.

3. Does this update a previous service or business model, or is it completely new? For this question, more than a third of you said "completely new." Try to think broadly when you are considering where these crowdsourcing companies fit into the economy as a whole. (Think Silicon Valley's favorite buzzword: "disruption.") Most of these services being provided are not completely new, but they are directly competing with a service that was traditionally supplied by a brick-and-mortar company in a more centralized manner. Uber competes with taxi companies, Airbnb with hotel chains, Coursera with higher education universities. This is part of what makes crowdsourcing so exciting! 

4. (Not a major conceptual flaw, but speaks to the tech market today.) Getting venture capital funding is not a business model. (Smart) investors don't invest in a company who says their plan for generating revenue is to "get money from investors." When in doubt about the company's business plan, it is probably "ads". :-)  

Feel free do ask questions! Few of these concepts are clearly defined, and there are lots of ways to think about any one company. The main thing is to keep an open, creative perspective when thinking about how crowds can solve problems, and what technology can enable them to do so. 

Have a great weekend everyone!

history.subject: Take-aways from your company profiles

history.content:
Hi Everyone!

We have finished grading your company profiles, and I wanted to highlight some common misunderstandings (if that is the right word) that cropped up in many of your assignments. As we go forward in the class, and especially as you all begin to think about your final projects, make sure you are keeping a very open mind of what constitutes "crowdsourcing." Don't get too stuck in the Mechanical Turk/Crowdflower/micro-tasking mindset. 

1. Users vs. Contributors-- Many of you seemed confused about what constitutes a user vs. a contributor. In many crowdsourcing companies, this line is blurry- or nonexistent! Many companies you looked at fit what can be thought of as a "data-mining" model (e.g. Yelp, Foursquare), in which the primary service being provided depends on using data and modeling observed patterns of behavior-- e.g. to target ads or to recommend products. In these cases, the users are the contributors-- everyone who participates provides data, and everyone uses everyone else's data. This is an awesome crowdsourcing model because it is (ideally) self-sustaining and self-incentivizing. The more a person contributes (by providing more data about themselves), the better product they receive (e.g. better recommendations). 

2. Aggregation-- Many of the companies we look at fit into the "match-making" or "marketplace" model (e.g. Uber, Airbnb, Etsy). This is a very common case in which the company is simply working to match supply with demand, where the suppliers (e.g. drivers, in the case of Uber) and the consumers (riders) are distributed all over, and may have trouble finding one another otherwise. Here, rating systems etc. are one piece of the platform that might require aggregating, but arguably the more interesting aggregation problem is how to match a supplier with a consumer. Is this through preference-based recommendation systems (as in the data-mining model discussed above), through location-based matching, through bidding/price? Making these matches is non-trival, but crucial to making the company function.

3. Does this update a previous service or business model, or is it completely new? For this question, more than a third of you said "completely new." Try to think broadly when you are considering where these crowdsourcing companies fit into the economy as a whole. (Think Silicon Valley's favorite buzzword: "disruption.") Most of these services being provided are not completely new, but they are directly competing with a service that was traditionally supplied by a brick-and-mortar company in a more centralized manner. Uber competes with taxi companies, Airbnb with hotel chains, Coursera with higher education universities. This is part of what makes crowdsourcing so exciting! 

4. (Not a major conceptual flaw, but speaks to the tech market today.) Getting venture capital funding is not a business model. (Smart) investors don't invest in a company who says their plan for generating revenue is to "get money from investors." When in doubt about the companies business plan, it is probably "ads". :-)  

Feel free do ask questions! Few of these concepts are clearly defined, and there are lots of ways to think about any one company. The main thing is to keep an open, creative perspective when thinking about how crowds can solve problems, and what technology can enable them to do so. 

Have a great weekend everyone!

history.content:
You can use an XPath selector to ignore anything contained in a title tag. For instance, the following selector says "select all the text nodes which do not have a title tag as an ancestor":

//text()[not(ancestor::title)]

You can try it out on this site: http://www.freeformatter.com/xpath-tester.html. For instance, when running it on the following HTML fragment, the text in the two p tags will be selected, but the title text will be ignored:

<html>
  <head>
    <title>Ignored</title>
   </head>
   <body>
     <p>Selected</p>
     <p>Also selected</p>
   </body>
</html>

Note that you will get a bunch of empty strings, since every tag is considered to have text, even if it's the empty string. There are ways arounds this in XPath, but that's a bit beyond the scope of what you're asking.

https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/cloudfactory#/entity
http://www.careerbliss.com/cloudfactory/reviews/
http://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=231678267
https://www.linkedin.com/company/cloudfactory-com		Other than the company's website, I did not attempt to use the service or conduct any interviews.A trained and monitored "crowd labour" management company that seeks to improve on the crowdsourcing model provided by Mechanical Turk.http://www.cloudfactory.com/homehttp://cdn2.hubspot.net/hub/351374/file-1347457928-png/img/Logo_copy.png?t=14539790435112008Mark SearsFrom their website: "Someone once told me that, "Geeks will change the world!". So what would happen if a bunch of geeks moved their families to a third world country and did a tech startup to fight poverty and change the world?"

Apparently some people went to Nepal with a simple mission to change the world with tech for all the humanitarian reasons, and so they agreed the crowdsourcing model is broken and they wanted to improve upon it.		Privately held companyThe company provides the service of giving other companies a cloud-sourced workforce to scale up working, giving them a labor force that is closely monitored and regulated, so that it has all the benefits of cloud sourcing but is more fair and provides better more reliable results than standard crowdsourcing sites (such as MTurk)Updates a previous modelIt replaces the crowdsourcing model of sites like MTurk with a "cloud labor" model of a highly regulated and trained workforce.clickworker (https://www.clickworker.com/en/crowdsourcing-glossary/cloud-labour/)A business owner can use this very similarly to the way that researchers and other business owners use MTurk; however, the structure of the system sets clear guidelines and allows the owner to expect a certain quality of the work completed.

Workers can expect training and a host of regulations and rules to learn that will allow CloudFactory to do quality control.		More contributors than usersAnyone can contribute, though they do have a core staff that manages the site and production. However, signing up as a worker is as simple as watching a video and verifying your credentials.
Note that some of the job requirements are extremely specific - they really are looking for the high end of the workforce. For example, a job listing right now requires a Bachelor's in Business Administration, over 7 years experience working in the US/Europe, 5 years professional project management experience, and so forth.		One thing that motivates people to contribute is that they get to work in teams. Often, groups of 8 are required to apply together before you can start working - so it is appealing to the workers that they get to be working alongside, if not physically alongside, their friends. Also, while I could not get accurate information relating to how well they pay workers, but they seem to indicate from the qualifications of the people they are hiring that it really is a wage much above what a worker can expect on MTurk.NoYesThe company generates revenue by being paid by other companies for managing the workforce.Above, I mentioned the extremely strict qualifications required to do many of their jobs, such as having years of professional experience, even a 4-year degree in business, etc. Their workers are highly educated and professional.NoN/ANoN/AThere is no information on thisSpecific services are broken into categories (text, voice, images, web) and a user signs up for the service, contracting a solution with CloudFactory. Then contributers handle the backend, and results are funneled from CloudFactory to the contracting company. Generally speaking, this service is not done for individuals or researchers, but rather as a business model.While there is not a count of users, they aim to reach an employment of "1 million", but only have roughly 26 thousand facebook likes.I'm not sure what this means, but their total equity funding is $5.7 million.I think this would work well. They probably could use their own service. In fact, it's one of the key points the company makes in its presentations - that their workforce is scaleable without the loss of control over quality or price.This company seems too small to attract any type of controversy. According to LinkedIn, they have a workforce between 1001-5000 workers, and from the very little amount of attention they get on the internet, there's not much to talk about. Considering how they compare to current models, I don't believe they could be the target of controversy. Paraphrased from their site: they believe talent is equally distributed around the world, but opportunity is not. How can that be controversial?I feel like most of the informattion on the website and in articles around it were more promotional due to their social vision of bringing jobs to a workforce that does not currently have the oportunity to use their talents. however, most of it's procedural information is kept until the money flows. Therefore, it's very difficult to evaluate from the outside.

1) I couldn't find an email in spam, trash, inbox, etc. for my nets homework grade.  Can I have it re-emailed to me? (brodylan@sas.upenn.edu)

2) Is there any way I can see my responses to the survey about my Market Research company? I did not record  all of the information I found and so it would be easier to see my responses then dig it all up again.

history.content: I edited get_clean_text.py to catch all exceptions, so if any error occurred for a url, the script would continue to the next one.

children.subject: Instead of calling read() immediately on the result from urlopen(url), first call getcode() on it; if the response code isn't 200, then there was an error, so you should just skip it.
I'm having trouble writing this out in code. Do we just add urllib2.getcode(url) before the line with urlopen(url)?
You mean in addition the the try catch loop already in the code?
The existing try catch specifies an HTTPError, but as the stacktrace shows, the error being thrown is a URLError.

A try catch looks like this

try:
   myFunction()
   # Do other stuff here
except Exception:
   continue;

or with multiple exception types it looks like

try:
   myFunction()
   # Do other stuff here
except (Exception1, Exception2):
   continue;
Isn't there already a try-catch loop in the code? Why isn't that catching this exception?

history.content:
Hi everyone,

Here are the slides for today's lecture: Taxonomy of crowdsourcing and human computation

Here are the two readings that accompany it:

  • Human Computation: A Survey and Taxonomy of a Growing Field by Alex Quinn and Ben Bederson
  • Worker Evaluation in Crowdsourcing: Gold Data or Multiple Workers? by Panos Ipeirotis

Today's lecture was based on the first paper, and the second reading is a blog post that analyzes whether it's better to have gold data or to use multiple workers. 

As always, I invite you to ask questions or start a discussion about the lecture in the comments of this post.

--CCB

history.content:
If it's mostly correct, that likely reflects that get_clean_text is working how you expect. 

A good way to check this is to go to the URL that produced an output that we wouldn't want crowdworkers to label (because it doesn't make a ton of sense). get_clean_text.py grabs all the contents of <p> tags, which is usually text. Is it actually in non-English characters? That's valid for a page, and if it's in the minority, it won't affect our final results much. If the page is in English, but the beautiful soup output isn't, then there's probably something going wrong in the script. If the contents of the <p> tags are html tags themselves when you view the page source, then the administrators of the website probably just didn't write clean html.

history.content:
Quick answer:

pip install --user <package>

Installs the package in your local home directory (so you don't need to go through the setup steps above as that automatically is included in your $PYTHONPATH).

Long answer:

You cannot install packages system-wide by yourself on Eniac. 

You can install a package to a local directory using the command below. This will install the package into the directory you specify (e.g. somewhere in your home directory, where you can write to), rather than to a root directory (which you do not have permission to install into). 

pip install --install-option="--prefix=DIRECTORY/TO/INSTALL/IN" package_name

The only catch is you will need to tell python to look in whatever local directory you installed into, since python doesn't know to look there by default. I recommend doing the following. 

$ mkdir /home1/e/epavlick/software # make a directory that you will install all your things into (use your username)
$ pip install --install-option="--prefix=/home1/e/epavlick/software" package_name #install the package into that direcotyr
$ echo "PYTHONPATH=$PYTHONPATH:/home1/e/epavlick/software/lib/python2.7/site-packages" >> ~/.bashrc # add this directory to your PYTHONPATH, which tells python where to look for installed packages
$ source ~/.bashrc # in short, "refresh" your shell

Hopefully this will work! Let us know if you have trouble.

history.content:
Hi everyone, 

We've had a chance to look through submissions for HW3 and while it'll be a few days before grades are ready to be sent out, we wanted to offer some feedback and clarification. Most of you had really high accuracies and many of you noted that accuracy was "higher" when you eliminated cross-validation because of overfitting (in the same way scores are higher when the midterm matches the practice test very closely). 

X represented the full set of articles. y represented the labels. There were hundreds of thousands of unigram features, because features corresponded to each word that appeared (repeats did not contribute to # of features -- see 'that guy shot that other guy' for an example). 

This week, you are re-training your classifier on the full set of articles that we gave you last week ('articles' is the name of the text file) and then output predictions on the new URLs you collected. You'll want to modify the code for your statistical classifier to generate the labels for crowdworkers to check - the file on the assignment page is a great start towards that. 

If you have any questions, please come to office hours sooner rather than later and post to Piazza if your question hasn't already been asked. Some parts of this assignment just take time to finish -- crawling, waiting for crowd worker judgements, the questionnaire -- and it's better to leave yourself time to debug.
history.subject: Using your classifier in HW4: Becoming a Requester

history.content:
You can kind of view html as a file system 

<abc>
   <def>
      <xyz attribute_name=attribute_value />
   </def>
</abc> 
So abc/def will get you the nose xyz
abc//xyz will recursively search all child of abc for xyz 
abc//@attribute_name will get you all the attribute values 
you can do node/text() to get the text inside a node
<node> text here </node>

You can kind of view html as a file system 
<abc>
<def>
<xyz attribute_name=attribute_value />
</def>
</abc> 
So abc/def will get you the nose xyz
abc//xyz will recursively search all child of abc for xyz 
abc//@attribute_name will get you all the attribute values 

you can do node/text() to get the text inside a node
<node> text here </node>

Hi Hannah,

We will not be grading you on your design choices, so you should feel free to pick whatever format is easiest for you and gets the job done. In the end, you will probably need to store the full text of each article anyway (since that is what your classifier will need) so if you want to store the full html pages locally and you have the space to do so, feel free.

That said, you shouldn't need to use beautiful soup in order to pull out the title/date fields. These should actually be available to you via the bing api, before you even access the full html page. We discussed this a bit in @177.

history.content:
Hi everyone. 

I had an error with running the given method and went to office hours, and a TA added some stuff to the get_clean_text.py file to make it actually run. The error came from invalid urls. If you are having this problem, I would suggest redefining the method get_text(url) as follows. When you do this, also add 

import sys

to the top of your file.

def get_text(url) : 
  """
  This is a method for extracting the text from a url using BeautifulSoup. 

  url- string of the url from which we want to extract text
  """
  try:
    soup = BeautifulSoup(urllib2.urlopen(url).read(), 'html.parser')
    ret = ''
    for p in soup.find_all('p'): 
      ret += ' '.join(p.text.encode('utf-8').split())
    return ret
  except:
    sys.stderr.write("ERROR IN URL: "+url+"\n")
    return ""

Hope this helps you!

children.subject: Or since the value of our questions is calculated automatically (it's uneditable), is it auto-paying $0.01/answer

The Automatic Payments feature works by adding a specific amount (that you specify) every time your "Available Funds" fall below $10. Any payments that your crowdflower account makes to workers should be from your "Available Funds" which should be $50 at the moment. 

If automatic payments is disabled (which I would recommend), you'll just get an email if your available funds fall below $10. Also, before you post your jobs, CrowdFlower will give you an estimate of how much it expects the job to cost.

Dylan Mannmannd@seas.upenn.edumanndNoWikipedia's AI helperhttp://www.wired.com/2015/12/wikipedia-is-using-ai-to-expand-the-ranks-of-human-editors/
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:About
http://www.andreaforte.net/ForteBruckmanWhyPeopleWrite.pdf
https://blog.wikimedia.org/2015/11/30/artificial-intelligence-x-ray-specs/
http://www.theregister.co.uk/2012/12/20/cash_rich_wikipedia_chugging/		no, other than using wikipedia oftenWikipedia is a crowdsourced, free to use encyclopedia that uses AI to help find bad edits of articles.wikipedia.comhttps://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/80/Wikipedia-logo-v2.svg/1122px-Wikipedia-logo-v2.svg.png2001, AI editor began in 2015Jimmy Wales and Larry SangerIt began as an offshoot from another online encyclopedia Nupedia. Nupedia had strict rules and qualifications for who could edit and write articles. This resulted in extremely slow growth. The creators of Nupedia wanted to speed it up, so they decided to adopt a wiki model, where anyone could contribute to any article, but that was met with resistance from the users of the website, so they broke it off into its own project, Wikipedia.

The AI edit helper was created to encourage more contribution to articles. The contributing experience was very unfriendly to newcomers, so Wikipedia loosened up the restrictions and created an artificial intelligence algorithm to automatically detect malicious edits.		Non-profit organizationThe company provides a free encyclopedia that anyone can use online.Updates a previous modelNupedia, an online encyclopedia, that had much stricter restrictions about who could edit the articles on the site.http://www.encyclopedia.com/ (free)
http://www.britannica.com/ (pay to use, based off print)

a somewhat complete list of online encyclopedias is available here:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_online_encyclopedias		If you want to learn more about a company (say Netflix), you can go to wikipedia's website and search for 'Netflix', where there is a rich, informative article, written by unpaid contributors, that explains all about the company, its origin, awards it has won, controversies it was involved in, etc.

the AI helper will automatically flag any edits with a rating, and whether it thinks the edit is good or bad, allowing humans to more easily handle malicious, biased, or incorrect edits.		More users than contributorsAnyone with internet access can contribute to wikipedia. According to the website, about 70,000 people are regular contributors.The people are motivated to contribute simply because they enjoy spreading knowledge to the world and improving a free resource. There is also an indirect system of rewards, watched articles, and other resources that allow contributors to improve their reputation among the community.YesNoWikipedia is entirely funded by small donations from users and large donations from other companies, such as Google and the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation.The contributions of others who watch many articles, and also an AI algorithm that detects malicious edits. Users or IP addresses that have been flagged for bad edits are sometimes blocked from contributing any more.NoNoThe contributions are a series of edits to the original articles (also written by the contributors). The latest edit is the one that appears online for the world to see.The service is not often advertised anymore, as it is one of the 10 most visited sites on the internet, but it is usually billed as "the free encyclopedia that anyone can edit." The contributors contribute by going to an article they want to edit, then you can either make an account, or simply edit the page as your IP address. In the end, users get access to a huge base of knowledge about almost anything they wish to learn.374 million unique visitors monthly (as of last september)N/AIt would be very difficult to scale Wikipedia to 100 times its current size, as I'm not sure that much information exists to add, however, it is one of the largest bases of information currently on the internet, and there is no real incentive scheme, so I believe it is scaleable, as long as the contributors remain the same quality and the AI editor quality continues to improve.In the past there were questions about its revenue generating model, and the donations it has solicited. Currently, Wikipedia is awash with cash (it even has a lobbyist), and still asks for donations every holiday season.

history.content: If all went well, get_clean_text.py should output ~3200 lines. Check that execution of the program completed without any errors/uncaught exceptions. If you want to try again, I'd suggest printing when an exception is handled (see @199)

history.content:
There won't be an extension. Even if you launched it tonight, Crowdflower uses a lot of channels to recruit enough workers to keep up with demand. The word search I showed in class took about thirty minutes to complete with a hundred answers, and the limiting factor there was how long it took them to find five words (recruiting 500 workers vs. 100 workers doesn't extend the time by much). We recommended starting it early to give yourself time to debug and really look at the results and think carefully about steps in the process that affect accuracy. 

The video doesn't really affect the timeline for this assignment because we released it three weeks ago. That said, we know life happens and this is why we have a fairly generous late day policy with five days to use, and the penalties for submitting late work aren't very harsh after that (1 point per day). If you do turn it in after the deadline, both partners will use up a late day. 

If you're having trouble, there's still time to get help and we're happy to answer questions about HIT design and accessing the results. There are office hours taking place now until 4pm, and again from 6-8pm. Ellie is holding OH tomorrow from 12-2pm for last minute questions.

history.content:
Your questionnaire was submitted twice (once by you, once by your partner) and graded twice by me and by Ross Mechanic. We took the higher of the two grades. 

Some comments:

-1 service is compared to taxis and was previously provided by professionals; -1 service is typically regulated by government (medallion system) - this is an area of major controversy and many cities have banned Uber or held protests; this should have been discussed

-1 for saying that Uber was a completely new business model. It updates the taxi business model

The key takeaway is that people were able to get rides from strangers/professional drivers before. Now it's fulfilled by a crowd via Uber, updating a previous model. By business model, we were looking at the service that they provide (rides) - you noted this by comparing it to taxis in one of your responses.

In my score report for the market research questionnaire (homework 2), it says I received -1 for "saying that Uber was a completely new business model. It updates the taxi business model."  
 
By new business model, I wasn't referring to the already established model of drivers picking up riders; rather, I meant that Uber is a new business model in the way that it connects drivers and riders through a mobile app, and then takes a percentage of the profit.  Please let me know your thoughts on this.
 
Thanks,
Nick Wein

history.content: I *believe* that CrowdFlower (unlike MTurk) pays all of the workers, regardless of whether or not they give correct answers on your test questions. The consequence to workers for answering incorrectly is that CrowdFlower's "trustworthiness" score for that worker goes down, and workers who are not trustworthy enough may be blocked from doing future tasks. By forgiving, you recover their trustworthiness. (We will discuss the "trustworthiness" and quality control mechanisms a bit more later in the semester.)

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freelancer		No.Upwork is a global freelancing platform where businesses and independent professionals connect and collaborate remotely.https://www.upwork.com/https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Upwork-logo.svg/512px-Upwork-logo.svg.pngElance-oDesk was formed in a merger between Elance and oDesk in 2014 and was rebranded and relaunched as Upwork in 2015.oDesk was founded in 2003 by Odysseas Tsatalos and Stratis Karamanlakis. Elance was founded in 1999 by Beerud Sheth.Since Upwork was formed by merging two existing companies, its origin story is not especially interesting. Elance and oDesk merged to form Elance-oDesk, combining ideas, technology and resources. With the oDesk platform as the foundation, Upwork kept the best of both original companies and worked to add new innovations.Privately held companyUpwork creates an global online workplace for clients and businesses to find freelance professionals. These professionals can be anything from writers to an entire team of professionals.Updates a previous modelUpwork is a combination/update of Elance and oDesk.There are many other freelance platform services. Some are listed below:
Toptal
Freelancer
Craigslist (parts of it)
Guru
iFreelance
CrowdSource
Outsource.com		If you are looking to hire a freelancer, you list your needs and Upwork matches you with the freelance professionals. Clients using Upwork can be anyone from large companies to small businesses to single individuals.More contributors than usersAnyone with some professional skill and/or experience (as well as Internet of course) can create a freelancer profile on Upwork with their resume and accomplishments. Since it is free to join Upwork, the people who contribute services come from a large variety of backgrounds.One major selling point of Upwork is flexibility and freedom. People can work from home and do not need to commute anymore. Freelancers can also choose which jobs to accept and which clients to work with. Additionally, Upwork provides opportunities to work with clients worldwide. Finally, Upwork also helps freelancers manage their projects and helps ensure that they get paid.YesYesUpwork collects 10 percent of the payment to the independent professional. No fee is charged to those offering jobs.Upwork has voluntary skill tests as well as a feedback/reputation system to help clients find freelancers they can trust. The clients can interview the freelancers that want the job and the two parties can agree upon either hourly pay or fixed-price contracts. Upwork also has a timesheet application that tracks the work of freelancers. In addition to tracking time, the app also takes screenshots to ensure that freelancers are billing fairly. Finally, in the case of disputes, Upwork has a 24/7 customer service team and also helps with dispute resolution.YesThe intents of the government regulations are to protect company employees. Previously, employers had classified some of their employees as independent contractors/freelancers to avoid paying certain taxes and to avoid properly compensating their workers. Upwork meets these standards because all of the contributors are independent contractors/freelancers, so they are not being misclassified.YesUpwork uses a feedback system based on a Job Success score and a Top Rated status. The Job Success score is a percentage that is positively influenced by factors including client feedback, long-term relationships, and repeat contracts and is negatively influenced by factors such as contracts without activity and lack of communication or feedback. A Job Success score of over 90% is considered very good. Upwork members can earn a Top Rated status if they have a Job Success score of over 90%, have over $1000 in earnings in the past year, have an up-to-date and completed profile, have accurate availability statuses for new jobs and contracts, and have no recent account holds. Freelancers with these reputation points are more trustworthy and reliable in the eyes of the clients due to a strong track record. There are also client profiles with freelancer feedback that the freelancers can browse to decide if they want to work for a certain client.The contributions are not aggregated.Based on their needs, users are matched with professionals. The users can browse profiles and proposals to decide who they want to hire. The contributors can look at comments on user profiles to decide if they want to work for a given user. There is also a real-time chat platform to help in this process. After payment terms are negotiated, the contributors do the work they are contracted to do. They must do their work in a reasonable time period to avoid affecting their Job Success scores. Finally, the contributors are paid through Upwork's escrow system and the users receive the work that was completed.Over 4 million registered clientsOver $1 billion in annual work doneSince the contributors are not aggregating their work for the clients, if the company were to scale up, the current business model would probably still work. The incentive scheme wouldn't need to change because the users and contributors can still agree on the payment scheme with Upwork taking 10% of the payments. The quality model would also still work because every interaction is between a single user and a single contributor so the feedback system would probably still work. There is not really an aggregation model for Upwork. Considering the company is already operating on the scale of millions of users and contributors, scaling up 10 or 100 times more would probably not break Upwork's business model.I couldn't find any major controversies.Another URL of a company logo:

history.content: 'articles' is what we named the text articles we gave you last week. unlabeled_articles.txt is what you named the output of get_clean_text.py, which goes and pulls the text between <p> tags on the pages corresponding to the URLs you collected. So you'd expect to get as many unlabeled articles as URLs.

'articles' is what we named the text articles we gave you last week. articles.txt is probably what you named the output of get_clean_text.py, which goes and pulls the text between <p> tags on the pages corresponding to the URLs you collected. So you'd expect to get as many articles as URLs. But you can name articles.txt whatever you want if you think it's too similar.

history.content:
Hi all!

We have finished grading your classifier assignments, and you should get your grades shortly if you have not already (look for an email from Kate!). You guys did very well overall. It was not an easy assignment and there were a lot of new concepts that you had to take in (and new packages you had to install) all at once, so very well done. 

There were two common points of confusion. Please feel free to ask questions here or in OHs if you are having trouble with these concepts, since they are important if you intend to do more ML in the future.

What exactly are X and y? What are their dimensions? 

In short, y is a vector of labels (one label per article). X is a matrix of features (one row per article, one column per feature). (You might prefer to think of X as a list of vectors of features). A key point is that every article has a value for every feature-- so every article (row) has the same number of features (columns) associated with it. What changes are the values of those features (e.g. 0 or 1 in our assignment). Since the "features" in our case were words, the number of features (number of columns of X) is equal to the number of words in our vocabulary (this was probably ~300,000-500,000 in our dataset, depending on your preprocessing). If the word appeared in the article, the value for the word is 1 for that article, and if it did not appear, the value is 0. 

You are not alone if you find this concept a bit abstract. The biggest hurdle to overcome when learning about ML is getting comfortable thinking about your data as a feature matrix. Once you have internalized this notion, the rest of ML is reasonably straightforward. Please, ask us questions!

False positives and false negatives 

Many of you were confused by the concept of false positives and false negatives. A *false positive* in our case is an article that should have been labeled "not gun related" (0) but was falsely labeled "gun related" (1). These were likely articles with words like "shoot" but which referred to sports or movies instead of violent crimes. A *false negative* is an article that should have been labeled "gun related" (1) but was falsely labeled "not gun related" (0). Its good to think about these different types of errors when you are working on prediction tasks-- often different types of errors have different costs, or one type of error is worse than another.  (E.g. in medicine, tests that produce many false negatives are usually considered worse that ones that produce false positives. I'm sure you can think of some reasons why?)

 

But what now? My life has been so empty since turning in that classifier assignment... 

Many of you have expressed interest in learning more about machine learning, and you should absolutely consider enrolling in penn's ML course or penn's intro ML course. history.content:
My code for get_misclassified_examples was:

def get_misclassified_examples(y, X, texts) :
	x_train, x_test, y_train, y_test, train_texts, test_texts = train_test_split(X, y, texts)
	clf = train_classifier(x_train, y_train)

	for i, x in enumerate(x_test):
		expected_label = y_test[i]
		test_acc = test_classifier(clf, x, [expected_label])
		if expected_label == 0 and test_acc == 0.0:
			print test_texts[i]

Where I tried to identify the false positive rows, by checking if the true value was 0, but the resulting prediction was 1 and hence the test_acc was 0.

I was deducted marks for this. Please let me know if I made a mistake here. Thank you!

history.content:
"Retainer" is a term that means a payment made to someone to wait to act until you need their services. For instance, you can keep a lawyer on retainer, meaning you pay them to be ready to act on your behalf when you need them too. 

In this case I think that paper means for wait time up to .5 minutes, they paid 2 cents. For wait times up to 1 minute they paid 4 cents. ... For wait times up to 30 minutes they paid 32 cents.

"To test how long we could keep workers primed, we experimented incremented retainer time to vary between 0.5 1 2 5 10 and 30 minutes. We scaled payment roughly linearly with retainer time : 2, 3, 4, 7, 12, 32 cents. "

What does retainer time refer to? I thought it meant latency time but it doesn't make sense for them to pay someone more for a higher latency.

history.content:
Reading "Running Experiments on Amazon Mechanical Turk," and I came across this claim, which reminded me of problems with the Columbia Small Worlds Problem, where there was very low participation rate (99K registered, 24K initiated chains, 384 reached targets).

Critiques of Milgram's "6 degrees of separation" result (people knew how to find a short path to any random person) highlight the low participation and completion rates (64 of the 296 chains reached the target in the 1960s experiment). Would it be possible/worthwhile to recreate the experiment on MTurk?
history.subject: Re: "Mechanical Turk strongly diminishes the potential for non-response error in online research"
