history.content: How can we find hourly wage through CrowdFlower? Do we need to estimate it or there is a section that gives a precise number?
history.subject: Hourly Wage on CrowdFlower

history.content:
Hi everyone, 

Grades have been sent out for "Becoming a Requester." If you haven't received the email, and it's not in your spam folder, you can complete the form here and I will try to get your grades back to you by midnight (which is also the drop deadline). 

Overall, you did very well with it and are now masters of crawling the internet. You gained some new tools that you should keep in mind for the final project (and the first part has been released, yay!). 

We did see a few common misconceptions that we'd like to clear up. 

  • The hourly wage referred to what the workers completing your job earned (you can view this value on Crowdflower's analytics tab). Without simply paying more per task, the other variable we could affect was the amount of time it takes to complete. Making the links clickable, scraping the text of the article and uploading that to Crowdflower instead of URLs, and providing clear, unambiguous directions to make deciding the label easier were all great ways, but there's a lot that we can do on this side. 
  • Precision is the ratio of true positives over all positives, or the probability that once your classifier has labeled an article as gun violence, it's actually about an instance of gun violence. This differed from accuracy because accuracy is the ratio of correct labels over all labels (true positives + true negatives)/(all positives + all negatives). Some of you submitted definitions from other fields, and we would encourage you to go back through and review the slides. 
  • Recall is the ratio of (true positives)/(true positives + false negatives). For our data set, this was the probability that an article about gun violence would be given a positive label by our classifier. We couldn't calculate that because we only gave the Crowdflower workers positively-labeled data, and therefore can't draw any conclusions about the number of false negatives in our labels. 
  • Within the Bing API piece, many of the titles submitted were "News Result." This is a field in the Bing API, but doesn't correspond to the actual title of the article (or it would be very difficult to decide which articles to read). 
  • There are a lot of sources of bias in the way that we collected data. One of our goals is to minimize this. It's easy to see that minor injuries are unlikely to be reported, that areas with less media coverage are less likely to be scraped (some of you started with the New York Times and the LA Times, but nobody checked any newspapers from the middle of nowhere), that reporting around gun violence can be sensationalized and since we aren't deduplicating results yet, there are likely repeat incidents that were reported on at multiple URLs you submitted. There are other sources too, and thinking about this is an important part of building a comprehensive system to measure anything (not just gun violence). 
  • Some of you got really original with what you named the files that you submitted. While we appreciate your creative genius, it makes it a lot easier to grade when the names of files approximately correspond to what's in them. Please keep this in mind for future assignments. 

If you have a regrade request or specific questions about your grades, you should come to office hours to discuss it.

children.subject:
Yes, you have to do that manually. You actually have to do that somewhat manually on MTurk, too. For both platforms, the assumption is that everyone will be paid the same for completing the same HIT. Its a pain in the ass, I agree.

If you use MTurk, there is a very handy Python library called boto. You can use it to grant bonuses programmatically, so you can avoid doing it manually. 

http://boto.cloudhackers.com/en/latest/ref/mturk.html

On a similar note, is there a way to automatically pay workers based on certain metrics (e.g. number of textboxes filled, number of pages completed, etc.) on CrowdFlower? Or do we manually have to award each worker a bonus based on their performance?

history.content:
I do not think there is an easy way to do this on CrowdFlower. As I believe Chris mentioned in class, there are a lot of good reasons to use Mechanical Turk for this assignment-- MTurk gives you a *lot* more flexibility over how you grade/approve/pay your workers, whereas CrowdFlower is quite restrictive. I would recommend one of the following:

1) Switching to MTurk, if you or your partner are able to create an account. This is probably your best option.

2) Switch the task you are using (e.g. don't use a word search, but think of something else). You will need to make sure your new task has all of the important properties of the word search task in order to stay true to the original study, for example, it is important that the task allows you to measure varying degrees of effort.

3) Post your task with no QC at all, and offer very low or no pay, and then grade the tasks yourself offline (either manually or with a script) and pay workers afterward via bonuses. This may not give you good results because workers may not accept your tasks if they don't trust you to bonus them, or spammers might use up all the no-QC tasks before any good workers can do them. 

4) There is a way to customize the QC on CrowdFlower but it requires running your own server that can process CF's requests as they come in. If you are comfortable with this kind of thing and want to go this route, I can forward you an email with the instructions for how to set it up.

Good luck!

--Ellie

history.content: For a given batch of jobs, I believe you can't have a varying payout schedule. The only way to vary the payout would be to issue these jobs separately. This will have compounding effects on results which you will have to account for in your findings.

history.content:
From the rubric on the course website: 

  • 1 point - for successfully executing the experiment on a crowdsourcing platform, and describing how you used the platform
  • 1 point - for analyzing your results and comparing them to the original paper

Be sure to answer these questions from the write-up: Are your high-level findings the same as the original paper or different? If they are different, how so? What do you attribute the differences to?

Explain what you did, differences in experimental setup, how it affected things, and if you can successfully justify why your set-up is apples-to-apples and tests the same ideas, you'll receive full credit for successfully executing the experiment. Be especially thoughtful in exploring the reasons for differences in results.

How closely do our results need to match the results of the research paper we implement? For the Financial Incentives and the Performance of Crowds paper, our team found that our "no pay" bracket did not actually perform better than the paid-per-performance bracket. We think, however, it is explained by the fact that our baseline pay for workers was SIGNIFICANTLY less that the baseline pay in the study ($0.05 vs. ~$2.88), which in turn led to less intrinsic motivation. If we can justify our results, despite them not aligning with the results of the paper, will that suffice to receive full credit?
history.subject: Replicating results

history.content:
Definitely! Here's one take on using analytics to make predictions: http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/how-fivethirtyeight-is-forecasting-the-2016-ncaa-tournament/

It would be awesome, and probably fairly effective (certainly better than one individual's picks), to incorporate the picks of everyone who fills out a bracket this season and use that to make your predictions. But like you said, if every person's inputs are weighted equally, those upsets are exactly where aggregating over huge numbers of picks would fail. You could instead assess predictor quality based on previous years' brackets and identify people who are great at predicting upset victories, and weight their inputs more heavily than the casual observer's - tons of ways to apply the material of this class to March Madness. :)

I'm wondering if the principle of wisdom of the crowds can play into picking teams in the  march madness bracket. More so, since the teams are only playing one game, there are obviously a lot of upsets that can and do occur, and many times those seem to not be well predicted. So my main question is can wisdom of the crowds effectively apply to picking teams in a March Madness bracket?
history.subject: Crowd sourcing and March Madness

history.content:
Basically we're creating a double array called votes, which is indexed by url and then label. For each url and each label, we go through each worker and add up the qualities of the worker that marked that url with that label, and store it at that spot. So in the delta function we're comparing each worker's labels against the label that we're currently indexed at in the array. 

Then we go through each url array in votes, and find the label with the highest score, and assign that label.

history.content: It's fine just like this. Although the formatting looks weird on your display, it's actually really easy for a program to read in and interpret the file.

Many terminals/editors just show tabs as padding until the next nth tab length from the start rather than a fixed number of spaces; since the usual length of a tab in a terminal is eight spaces, the second line pads to eight spaces from the margin, whereas the first and third pad to 16 (because the non-tab text at the start goes all the way to first tab boundary).

A kappa value of 0 means about 50% agreement, 1 means perfect agreement, -1 means complete disagreement. There is no expected value for kappa - you're just reporting how similar your labels were to Crowdflower's.

history.content:
The slides have a really great example of a very similar data set. In particular, I think you should look at the differences between the end of iteration 0 and iteration 1. The scores remain fractional until the differences between iterations become negligible, at which point you round to 0 or 1. The scores of the workers do carry over to the next iteration in assessing the "correct" labels. 

From slide 91: 

1. Estimate the probability that each answer is correct, using labels from multiple workers weighted by the probability that they are correct 

2. Estimate the quality of the workers by comparing their submitted answers to the inferred correct answers (inferred correct answers = labels)

def get_tau(file1, file2) :
	q1 = [line.split('\t') for line in open(file1).readlines()]
	qlist = {}
	for elem in q1 :
		qlist[elem[0]] = elem[1]

	q2 = [line.split('\t') for line in open(file2).readlines()]
	qlist2 = {}
	for elem in q2 :
		qlist2[elem[0]] = elem[1]

	list1 =[]
	list2 = []
	for i in qlist :
		if i in qlist2 :
			list1.append(qlist[i])
			list2.append(qlist2[i])

	tau, p_value = scipy.stats.kendalltau(list1, list2)

	print tau

history.content:
I think I understand your question, but let me know if I am not answering what you are asking. 

The worker quality is just the % of labels they provide that are "correct." You can think of it as, if a randomly grab a url and ask this worker to label it, what is the probability they will give me a correct response? The formula you gave should give the correct number for this. You can also just think of it as # correct / total. 

"Do we take the % of URLs that are porn and not porn from the true labels we calculated in iteration 2 or the ones we calculated iteration 1."

I agree that the terminology of iteration 1/iteration 2 etc is a bit confusing. You really have two steps going on-- one where you estimate labels and one where you estimate worker qualities-- and they are interleaved. So your process looks something like:

Labels iteration 1 <- based on simple majority vote

Worker Qualities iteration 1 <- based on Labels iteration 1

Labels iteration 2 <- based on Worker Qualities iteration 1

Worker Qualities iteration 2 <- based on Labels iteration 2

...

Labels iteration n <- based on Worker Qualities iteration n-1

Worker Qualities iteration n <- based on Labels iteration n

Does that help at all?

children.subject: just noticed this in your above diagram....shouldn't the labels based on simple majority vote be labels of iteration 0? sorry now im still confused as to whether we calculate % of URLs from previous or current iteration when calculating worker qualities.but im assuming what i mentioned above is still correct. please let me know

I started at 1 in that above diagram, but you are right, we probably call it 0 in the slides. But don't overthink the iteration numbers-- either way, you should always calculate the worker qualities based on your most recent estimate of the URL labels.

So when you start ("iteration 0") you have nothing to go on, so you compute URL labels based on simple majority vote. This is your best estimate of the URL labels, so you use this to compute worker qualities.

Then ("iteration 1") you update your URL labels taking into account the worker qualities you just computed. Now, you recompute the worker qualities, using the URL labels you just updated. Every time you compute worker qualities, you use your most up-to-date URL labels.

Not sure, but it might help to think about coding it. If you were to implement this programmatically, you would only keep one data structure for url_labels, and one for worker_qualities, and in each iteration, you would overwrite the old values. So when you go to compute worker qualities, you use whatever values are in currently in url_labels (which are always the most recent estimates).

I'll preface by saying I am doing my best to understand what you have currently, but its a little difficult to follow in writing. But keep in mind that the EM is at most one point of your overall grade on this assignment, so don't stress too much, you seem to be pretty close. :)

I think the iteration numbers are confusing you a bit. So iteration 0 of assigning labels is done using majority vote, like you said. Then iteration 0 of assigning worker qualities is done using the results of iteration 0 of assigning labels, which is your second bullet point. Iteration 1 starts when you recalculate labels (your third bullet point). 

Look at slide 14 of the lecture. This shows both update_labels and update_workers within the larger loop. You have to update both labels and workers before you move on to the next iteration.

i think im getting more confused because that contradicts the questionnaire and the lecture slides where it says that worker qualities are uniform in iteration 0. maybe the easier way is just to do #correct/total which would just be taking [(P,P) + (NP,NP)]/5? You are right, the questionnaire uses slightly different numbering than what was in the above post. I think all of the confusion is stemming from settling on what to call each iteration. Let's just stick to what is in the questionnaire. So:

Iteration 0 of Worker Qualities: Uniform (all equal)

Iteration 0 of Labeling URLs: Compute based on Iteration 0 Worker Qualities

Iteration 1 of Worker Qualities: Compute based on Iteration 0 Labels

Iteration 1 of Labeling URLs: Computer based on Iteration 1 Worker Qualities

Iteration 2 of Worker Qualities: Compute based on Iteration 1 Labels

Iteration 2 of Labeling URLs: Computer based on Iteration 2 Worker Qualities

It should be easy to see here why Iteration 0 Labeling URLs is equivalent to majority vote.

Should all the qualities be some fraction of 5 since the total number of urls is always 5? If I use the #correct/total equation I always get fractions of 5, but if I use the accuracy equation from above, then I don't.

They should be equivalent, I believe, if you actually compute accuracy for each class. I think the issue is that the equation as written above is in terms of precision (i.e. it only punishes false positives, not false negatives). Accuracy should punish both false positives and false negatives, and credit both true positives and true negatives.

The easiest thing is just to use #correct/total.
We will accept it either way.

history.content:
This error means you are trying to create more variables than you have values for. E.g. if you write

x, y = line.split()

this means you expect line.split() to return a list with two elements, you want to store the first element in a variable called "x" and the second in a variable called "y". It will throw the "need more than 1 value to unpack" error if line.split() returns a list with only one element.

You should try printing the lines within the loop and see which one is causing the error (i.e. does not contain two tab-separated elements).

history.content: Today, I reset my Snapchat password and discovered something very interesting. Instead of doing the traditional "type the letters you see in the box below" CAPTCHA, Snapchat's equivalent was asking me "Which of the following are pictures of mountains?" and displaying 9 images above that text, some of which were mountains and some of which were not. Now, I assume that they knew that some of those were definitely mountains ("gold labels") but, correct me if I'm wrong, I believe they were using me to help label their images for free, and I, as the "contributor," did not have much choice since I forgot my password. Genius!

history.content:
Are you having trouble using {{city_1}} as valu, or text? I.e. for a pull down form in html you have both fields that you can set, like

<select value="value">text</select>

CrowdFlower might have a problem with the value field matching a column that already exists. You can try appending something to the end of the string like "_answer" to make it unique. Or just make the value "city1" and do some post processing to resolve to a city name.

When designing the questions in CrowdFlower, how do we import our data (e.g., city_1, city_2, etc.) into the pulldown menu? I would have thought that we put {{city_1}}, {{city_2}}, etc. as the labels, but this gives me an error: '{{city_1}}' will show up in your results as 'city_1', which already exists as a header in your uploaded data.

How are we meant to label the answers in the pull down menu?
history.subject: Importing data into question labels

history.content:
You could try using a regex to condense multiple tabs into one, e.g.

import re

re.sub('\t+', '\t', url_text)

Yes, regex or string.replace() are easy ways to deal with extra tabs. You can replace tabs with blank spaces (' ') anywhere they appear.

There are some URLs from which the extracted text will give you a file with multiple tabs and it's pretty poorly formatted. You can use the following line of code to fix that

import re

txt = get_text(url)
clean_text = re.sub('\t+', '', txt)
#TODO process each line of input, and output the url and clean text (separated by a tab)
Yes, regex or string.replace() are easy ways to deal with extra tabs. You can replace tabs with blank spaces (' ') anywhere they appear.

A few things to look at:

- re.sub("\t+", "\t") will replace multiple consecutive tabs with one single tab. Is that what you want? Think of what happens when you call line.split('\t'). Look at

- Think more carefully about where in the code you should be calling the sub() method, and look at which line is throwing the error. If this line of code is supposed to prevent an error from occuring, it needs to be executed before the line causing the error is executed.

history.content: So, the problem was that my csv file had extra columns if the article's text contained tabs. What I did was split on '\t' to create a list, store the first value of that list as the url, and then join all the other values and store them as the text.

children.subject: Another method for this problem is to <articletext>.split('\t', MAXSPLIT) <--- where MAXSPLIT is the number tabs that split will split on. Setting this to 1 only splits on the first tab, and leaves the rest unchanged. After this, one can replace all the other article tabs with spaces.

history.content:
Add a print statement right before the error is thrown, so you know which line is causing the error. Otherwise, it is very hard to debug. E.g. 

for url in sys.stdin :
  sys.stderr.write('Processing url' + url + '\n')
  url, txt = url.strip().split('\t')

If you are worried about hitting your API limit, you can always just comment out the actual API calls in the script. This error is unrelated to the API call, and so you can run the script over and over while debugging.

Getting the ValueError: too many values to process when running my extract_entries.py. I know this error has been brought up in piazza before, but the solutions given haven't worked for me. I've removed the articles without text to process and all, but it won't run, and I'm afraid to keep running so that I don't hit the limit on the API. Can someone tell me what might be wrong with my code? 

Note: It will give about 33 lines of output before running into an error, but removing the next article didn't change anything. 

import sys
import urllib2
import json
import csv

# To run, type  the following into the terminal:
# cat gun-violence-urls-and-text.txt | python extract_entities.py > gun-violence-urls-and-text-annotated.txt

#  My Alchemy API key
api_key = '439d12cb72c484ecc556ba1a4595279d5ae94132'

def construct_api_call(url):
  return 'http://access.alchemyapi.com/calls/url/URLGetCombinedData?apikey=' + api_key + '&url=' + url + '&extract=title,pub-date,entity&outputMode=json'

def get_fields(url) :
  try:
    data = urllib2.urlopen(construct_api_call(url))
  except urllib2.HTTPError:
    sys.stderr.write('BAD REQUEST\n')
    return None
  try:
    response = json.loads(data.read())
  except ValueError:
    sys.stderr.write('JSON ERROR\n')
    return None
  if response['status'] == 'OK':
    title = response['title'].encode('ascii', 'ignore')
    date = response['publicationDate']['date'].encode('ascii', 'ignore')
    entities = json.dumps(response['entities'])
    return title, date, entities
  return None

for url in sys.stdin :
  url, txt = url.strip().split('\t')
  fields = get_fields(url)
  if fields is not None:
      title, date, entities = fields
      # format and output the url and text
      line = url + '\t' + title + '\t' + date + '\t' + txt + '\t' + entities + '\n'
      sys.stdout.write(line)

If you are interested in looking at the design of the Information Extraction HIT that Ellie and I have been working on, you can try out our version of the Information Extraction HIT on the Mechanical Turk Worker Sandbox.   We also have a couple of initial steps for having the workers validate the predictions of our gun violence classifier.  There's a HIT to tag gun violence articles based on their titles and another HIT to read the full text of articles for articles that were tagged as unclear in the headline HIT. 

These HITs were implemented by 10clouds, a software development firm that I use.  If your final project wins the $10,000 grand prize, then one option for how to spend that money is to hire 10clouds to do dev work to make your project into a real product.

children.subject: True - interpretation has very little to do with subjects like linear algebra or quantum physics.  However, you can still imagine that crowds might help you come to a more optimal way of teaching the subjects. One way of harnessing the large-scale of MOOCs for teaching such subjects might be to think about them as a form of A/B testing.  If we have several different ways of conveying the same topic, then randomly assign the students to one version or to the other.  Then measure how well they do on an assessment about the materials.  Even though there's an objective "right" and an objective "wrong" in the problem set, there is a lot of subjectivity in designing the educational materials that conveys a topic.

I think it would work well for subjects that can be taught interactively. I'm inclined to agree that it would be challenging for math. The barrier to entry for poetry is lower (literacy in English is better-managed than literacy in math), and so an interactive discussion can be established in any coffee shop without too much investment. 

Dr. Ghrist, of the Penn math department, recently gave a talk in a senior lecture series and stated that we need a Moore's Law for education - a way to teach advanced concepts in half the time (earlier, more quickly, better), so that we can build to greater discoveries. I think that's somewhat lacking in linear algebra. Not that it can't be done in an engaging way, but that it's easier to sit at the front of the room and explain then correct misconceptions than it is to converge on some understanding as a crowd. I'm optimistic that the way math is taught will improve over time, and that it will become simpler to make learning math engaging (and therefore more suitable for an effective MOOC). 

A good counterexample to the idea that only experts can be great contributors/participants in the sciences is fold.it - the volume of non-expert attempts is what makes it an effective way to study how proteins fold.

I thought that Al Filries gave an engaging and compelling discussion but ultimately I still have qualms with the overly generalized assertion that MOOCs would be an effective model for nearly all fields/subjects. Poetry at its core is, at the end of the day, entirely subjective. You can't say that my interpretation is somehow "wrong" just as how I can't tell you that your interpretation is "wrong". By allowing essentially mass, free discussion, more of these interpretations of poetry are generated and everyone is better off. However, imagine replacing poetry with linear algebra or quantum physics. I claim that there is little if not any wisdom in the crowd with respective to these subjects. In these fields, there is an objective "right" and an objective "wrong". Having 50,000 people from all around the world who have limited knowledge regarding Laplace transforms will not bring any significant insight into the matter. Adding 100,000 more people wouldn't help either.

history.content: The grades will be based on the total number of points you earn. If everyone earned an A, everyone would receive an A. Your main concern at this point in the semester should be producing a high quality final project, as that has potential to substantially impact your grade either positively and negatively.

How will the final grade be determined for the class? Is the class graded based on a curve or in an absolute scale? I think everyone receive homework scores, but none of us know how we are doing with respect to the whole class.

history.content:
Turkit may be a little out of date with the current version of Java and AWS, since its development ended a few years ago.  As a result, it might be hard to use.  Have you already tried using it with the examples?  You should start with the Java jar version, not the web one.

Another way of doing this would be to do two HITs:

1) Collect questions from the workers.

2) Upload the questions to a second pass HIT where those questions are now input.

If we're creating a web page that takes in information from some user, how do we use that information to create a hit on MTurk? More specifically, we're making a web page that accepts a question and we want post that question to MTurk. How can we use the TurKit to do that?

Thanks!
history.subject: Mechanical Turk and API
